awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  Soil Nutrient and Moisture Monitoring Probe Sensors to Optimize Fertilizer and Water Use
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to optimize fertilizer and irrigation in farming with data collected from novel sensors.   These sensors will continuously monitor soil nitrogen, salinity, and moisture throughout an entire growing season (up to four months). Currently, farmers usually do not measure these soil parameters because it requires them to tediously ship samples back to a laboratory for expensive analysis.  These sensors will provide a low-cost, on-site method to perform these soil parameter tests.  This project will improve soil and watershed health through reduced fertilizer runoff and irrigation water.  The data collected will inform soil parameter models to enable better predictions of regional soil health. This project's materials and sensors can be adapted to other monitoring applications, such as chemical pollution in watersheds and drinking water or remediation efforts at polluted environmental sites. The system will improve farming profit margins, environmental and public health, and water scarcity.   

The proposed project will advance sensors for agricultural monitoring. The objectives are to: (2) develop sensors to monitor nitrogen and salt concentration levels in the soil, (2) integrate the sensors into polymer-based probes that can be buried in a farm field, and (3) evaluate the completed sensor probe during an entire corn crop cycle. Anticipated challenges include: the simultaneous sensing of nitrogen, salinity, moisture, and conductivity; the longevity of sensors to last the entire growing season; acquiring sensor readings at different soil depths under different temperatures and pH; and powering and transmitting the sensor data to a handheld data logger.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Our NSF-supported project at Iowa State University, in collaboration with our industry partner, aimed to revolutionize agricultural practices by developing advanced sensors to monitor nitrogen and salinity levels in soil. These sensors, based on innovative laser-induced graphene (LIG) technology, were integrated into existing soil moisture probes, enabling continuous, real-time monitoring of soil nutrients.

The project's intellectual merit lies in its advancement of LIG technology for environmental monitoring. We refined the design and fabrication of ion-selective electrodes, enhancing their signal-to-noise response and longevity. These sensors can detect key soil nutrients and salts important for assessing soil fertility and water quality. Our research has expanded the understanding of how modifying the surface properties of graphene can dramatically improve sensor performance, which is pivotal for reliable long-term environmental monitoring. Further, we conducted a customer discovery exercise and interviewed many potential customers in the agricultural sector to understand better their pain points and learn about opportunities for innovation.

The broader impacts of our work include:

  1. Agricultural Efficiency: By providing precise, real-time data on soil conditions, our sensors allow farmers to optimize the use of fertilizers and water, leading to more sustainable farming practices and reduced environmental impact.
  2. Educational Opportunities: The project supported extensive training for students and postdoctoral researchers, equipping them with unique skills in cutting-edge sensor technology and preparing them for careers in academia and industry.
  3. Public Engagement: We actively disseminated our findings through academic publications, conference presentations, and direct interactions with the agricultural community, raising awareness of the benefits of precision agriculture.

The outcomes and achievements of our work include:

  • Successfully deployed over 100 sensor probes in fields across Iowa and Mississippi, demonstrating the practical application of our research.
  • Developed robust protocols for sensor manufacturing, significantly improving their hydrophobicity and signal stability, which are crucial for their operation in diverse environmental conditions.
  • Published findings in high-impact journals, submitted patents, and presented at major conferences and farm-progress shows, conducted interviews with potential customers, contributing to the scientific advances and translation of technology in environmental sensing and precision agriculture.

This project not only advanced the scientific understanding of graphene-based sensors but also translated these findings into practical tools for enhancing agricultural productivity and sustainability. The integration of these sensors into commercial soil and water probes stands as a testament to the project's success in bridging the gap between research and real-world application, marking a significant step forward in the pursuit of sustainable agriculture.

 


Last Modified: 01/17/2025
Modified by: Jonathan C Claussen
